Award.AwardTitle: The Three-Dimensional Flow Structure and Forces of Flapping-Wing Hovering from Experiments

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Ringuette, Matthew
1336548

The research objective of this proposal is to understand the unsteady, 3D flow structure produced by a flapping wing in hover, how it relates to the forces, and the effect of key parameters such as stroke amplitude. In nature, flapping wings have low aspect ratios (ARs), and due to the high angles of attack and low Reynolds numbers flow separation and roll-up into vortices occurs.

Intellectual Merit
Wings in hover are known to generate highly 3D, interconnected vortex loops, which shed each half-stroke and create an overall downward jet-like flow to sustain the body weight. Prior experiments using animals or mechanical models, coupled with flow visualization or 2D digital particle image velocimetry (DPIV), have shed light on the loop structure, but the 3D vortex topology and its relationship to the lift force remain open topics. Computational studies focusing primarily on animal configurations provide greater detail and insight. However, there is a lack of experimental, 3-component 3D DPIV data, and the effects of parameters such as half-stroke amplitude, AR, and motion program on the flow structure are not well understood. A key question is: why do hovering animals flap with amplitudes of 3-5 chord lengths? The approach is to perform experiments using a 2-degree-of-freedom flapping-wing model with simplified wing geometries and motions. The goals are to understand the 3D vortex topology, its variation with half-stroke amplitude, AR, and velocity program, and how it relates to the forces. Of interest are changes in the vortex structure for different cases. Diagnostics include dye visualization, stereoscopic DPIV (SDPIV) for 3-component velocity fields, and force measurements.

Broader Impacts:
This research will provide valuable insight into the design of highly-maneuverable bio-inspired micro air vehicles (MAVs). They can collect scientific information in complex environments, e.g. urban settings, caves, and disaster sites such as collapsed buildings after an earthquake, where conventional drones cannot operate. Moreover, they could operate efficiently in swarms to track the spread of a toxic gas plume, for example. The results of the proposed research will yield a greater understanding of the unsteady vortical flow and how kinematics and AR affect maximum lift, yielding design strategies for flapping-wing MAVs. The educational and outreach component, which focuses on engaging and mentoring students at many levels through hands-on research in bio-inspired propulsion, will motivate them to pursue higher education and careers in STEM. This addresses the need for a national workforce of exceptional scientists and engineers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this research on flapping-wing hovering was to use experiments to understand the unsteady 3D and swirling (vortex) flow, how it varies with key wing motion parameters, and its relationship to the lift-force produced. This work has applications to the design of small, bio-inspired drone aircraft, also known as micro air vehicles (MAVs). These MAVs would have greater agility than larger, more conventional drones, and therefore the capability to fly in confined and complex environments including corridors, caves, disaster sites, and urban canopies. Their main use is to gather real-time information in these environments for civilian and defense purposes, e.g. search and rescue at a disaster site, or reconnaissance.

 

We were interested in studying the detailed 3D flow, particularly when the wing turns around at the end of a half-stroke, called stroke reversal. It pitches rapidly (wrist-like motion) so that its new orientation will produce lift force again after the turnaround. We wanted to understand the change in the 3D flow with variations in the rate and timing of this pitching: whether it pitches fully before stroke reversal (advanced) or the pitching straddles stroke reversal (symmetric). The goal was to connect the flow and forces, and gain design insight for flapping-wing MAVs.

 

The technical approach was to perform experiments using a scaled model of a 2-degree-of-freedom (rotating and pitching) flapping-wing, with simplified wing shape and motions, in liquid-filled tanks. We first used colored dye visualization to determine the 3D flow (vortex structure) for the various motion cases described above. We 3D-printed a wing with internal dye tubes or channels, to deliver the dye to the wing edges as it flaps in water; we recorded videos of this. From this information, we created a detailed “skeleton”-type model of the 3D swirling flow, which deepened our understanding. Next, we used a laser-based imaging method, where the laser illuminates extremely small tracer particles in the flow, which are recorded by two cameras in stereo. This gave us quantitative measurements of the 3D flow velocity in slices. We used these data to gain knowledge of the strength of the various swirling flows, and understand how they vary over the cases studied, and how to scale this strength to relate it back to the wing pitching motion. We then employed a miniature, submersible device to obtain the lift force on the flapping wing directly, to see how it changed when the pitching was faster or slower, advanced or symmetric. This was related back to the flow information, so we could understand how the wing motion, flow, and lift force were connected.

 

The key findings related to flapping-wing MAV design are as follows. Extending the wing from the axis of rotation beyond a certain length, or aspect ratio, produces a loss in the flow coherence outboard, and somewhat reduced lift. An aspect ratio of less than 3-4 is recommended, similar to what is found for insect flight and by other research groups. After unsteady startup effects, a rotating wing produces near-constant lift coefficient. With higher pitching rate, the flow during pitching becomes quite complex and is highly 3D, but is well characterized by certain common features. The strength of the swirling flow from pitching can be reasonably scaled with the local wing-edge velocity, which will aid in future mathematical modeling efforts. Moreover, these behaviors are linked to the force during pitching, allowing trends to be predicted, although much more work is needed on this. Advanced pitching produces higher lift peaks, while symmetric pitching generates smaller peaks and more “even” or constant forces through each half-stroke. Symmetric pitching may be better in terms of structural loading, but advanced pitching could be beneficial for maneuvers. In all cases, increasing the pitch rate yields higher lift. This could be useful for maneuvering and handling disturbances in windy environments, but require more power. These results were disseminated in several conference presentations, a video compilation, and publications.

 

The educational and outreach component was focused on engaging and mentoring students at multiple levels via hands-on research in bio-inspired propulsion, to help motivate them to pursue higher education and careers in STEM. One Ph.D. student received his degree from this research. Moreover, 5 female students (2 high-school students, 2 undergraduates, 1 Ph.D. student) participated and gained valuable hands-on laboratory training and career mentoring. The first female high-school student went on to pursue an undergraduate mechanical engineering degree, and an undergraduate male student who participated later obtained an MS degree. The female Ph.D. student has continued to work with the PI on a new grant. Also, the results from the research were incorporated into the PI’s graduate class to enhance student learning. It is hoped that these positive experiences with STEM activities in an engaging, supportive, and rewarding environment created enthusiasm in those involved for pursuing further STEM education and careers.
